page.title: 17Wildlife in Cornwood
page.content: The largest wild animals to be seen in Cornwood are Fallow deer,inhabiting woodlands well away from houses. They are descended from deer set free from Blachford deer park,approx.25yrs. ago. Badger and fox tracks can be detected, while on riverbanks mink,and the occasional otter,fish for brown trout. Canada geese frequent Fardel and Blachford ponds in gaggles of 6 to 1O6 Buzzards fly high overhead,and a heron can often be seen following the course of a river.Rabbits,squirrels and small hedgerow mammals abound.In winter lapwings come down off of the moors. Tawny owls,cuckoos,magpies,jays and rooks are all common;and the collared dove is now much in evidence.At dusk the common toad emerges at the roadside,while bats swoop overhead.
